quotes.text: The illusion which exalts us is dearer to us than ten thousand truths.
quotes.author: Alexander Pushkin

quotes.text: Don't be sad, don't be angry, if life deceives you!
quotes.author: Alexander Pushkin
quotes.attribution: Attributed,  ~1830s. Continues: "Submit to your grief - your time for joy will come, believe me."

quotes.text: My whole life has been a pledge to this meeting with you.
quotes.author: Alexander Pushkin

quotes.text: I loved you, and I probably still do, And for a while the feeling may remain
quotes.author: Alexander Pushkin
quotes.attribution: I Loved You, 1829. Continues: "... But let my love no longer trouble you, I do not wish to cause you any pain."

quotes.text: All generalizations are dangerous, even this one.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas

quotes.text: In business, sir, one has no friends, only correspondents.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas

quotes.text: Moral wounds may be hidden, but they never close.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas

quotes.text: Philosophy is the application of the sciences to truth.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas

quotes.text: Wait and hope.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas

quotes.text: There is neither happiness nor misery in the world.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas
quotes.attribution: The Count of Monte Cristo, 1844. Continues: " there is only the comparison of one state with another."

quotes.text: Life is a storm, my young friend.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas
quotes.attribution: The Count of Monte Cristo, 1844. Continues: " You will bask in the sunlight one moment, be shattered on the rocks the next."

quotes.text: All for one, one for all, that is our device.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas

quotes.text: Never fear quarrels, but seek hazardous adventures.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas

quotes.text: Pure love and suspicion cannot dwell together.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas

quotes.text: The merit of all things lies in their difficulty.
quotes.author: Alexandre Dumas

quotes.text: 'Tis better to have loved and lost than never to have loved at all.
quotes.author: Alfred Lord Tennyson

quotes.text: Theirs not to reason why, theirs but to do and die.
quotes.author: Alfred Lord Tennyson
quotes.attribution: The Charge of the Light Brigade, 1854.

quotes.text: It is not only in Barchester that a new man is carrying out new measures.
quotes.author: Anthony Trollope

quotes.text: Morning parties, as a rule, are failures.
quotes.author: Anthony Trollope

quotes.text: Never think that you're not good enough yourself.
quotes.author: Anthony Trollope

quotes.text: No virtue could charm him, no vice shock him.
quotes.author: Anthony Trollope

quotes.text: The habit of reading is the only enjoyment in which there is no alloy.
quotes.author: Anthony Trollope

quotes.text: A man will give his life for a goat's horn.
quotes.author: Anthony Trollope

quotes.text: If one wants to keep one's self straight, one has to work hard at it.
quotes.author: Anthony Trollope

quotes.text: Love is like any other luxury. You have no right to it unless you can afford it.
quotes.author: Anthony Trollope

quotes.text: There is nothing perhaps so generally consoling to a man as a well-established grievance.
quotes.author: Anthony Trollope

quotes.text: Any idiot can face a crisis; it's this day-to-day living that wears you out.
quotes.author: Anton Chekhov

quotes.text: Don't tell me the moon is shining; show me the glint of light on broken glass.
quotes.author: Anton Chekhov

quotes.text: Life is infinitely stranger than anything the mind could invent.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: It is a capital mistake to theorize before one has data.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: Violence does, in truth, recoil upon the violent.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: London, that great cesspool.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle
quotes.attribution: A Study in Scarlet, 1887. Continues: " into which all the loungers and idlers of the Empire are irresistibly drained."

quotes.text: Nothing clears up a case so much as stating it to another person.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: The game is afoot!
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle
quotes.attribution: The Adventure of the Abbey Grange, 1904.

quotes.text: The smallest trace is often the way to the greatest truth.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle
quotes.attribution: The Adventure of the Cardboard Box, 1893.

quotes.text: Crime is common. Logic is rare.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle
quotes.attribution: The Adventure of the Copper Beeches, 1892.

quotes.text: There is nothing more deceptive than an obvious fact.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: The world is full of obvious things which nobody by any chance ever observes.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: You know my methods, Watson.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: I never guess. It is a shocking habit—destructive to the logical faculty.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: My mind rebels at stagnation. Give me problems, give me work.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: When you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: Mediocrity knows nothing higher than itself; but talent instantly recognizes genius.
quotes.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.text: The sea is as deep in history as it is in water.
quotes.author: Benito Pérez Galdós

quotes.text: To live is to see everything change.
quotes.author: Benito Pérez Galdós

quotes.text: Love is a great master. It teaches us to be what we never were.
quotes.author: Benito Pérez Galdós

quotes.text: The devil is not so black as he is painted.
quotes.author: Benito Pérez Galdós

quotes.text: I have always thought that a wild animal never looks so well as when some obstacle of pronounced durability is between us.
quotes.author: Bram Stoker

quotes.text: I sometimes think we must be all mad and that we shall wake to sanity in strait-waistcoats.
quotes.author: Bram Stoker

quotes.text: I want you to believe... to believe in things that you cannot.
quotes.author: Bram Stoker

quotes.text: Listen to them—the children of the night. What music they make!
quotes.author: Bram Stoker

quotes.text: No man knows till he has suffered from the night how sweet and dear to him is the morning light.
quotes.author: Bram Stoker

quotes.text: She has man's brain—a brain that a man should have were he much gifted—and woman's heart.
quotes.author: Bram Stoker

quotes.text: The world seems full of good men—even if there are monsters in it.
quotes.author: Bram Stoker

quotes.text: There is a reason why all things are as they are.
quotes.author: Bram Stoker

quotes.text: We learn from failure, not from success!
quotes.author: Bram Stoker

quotes.text: Remember, my friend, that knowledge is stronger than memory.
quotes.author: Bram Stoker
quotes.attribution: Dracula, 1897. Continues: " and we should not trust the weaker.

quotes.text: How blessed are some people, whose lives have no fears.
quotes.author: Bram Stoker

quotes.text: There are darknesses in life and there are lights.
quotes.author: Bram Stoker
quotes.attribution: Dracula, 1897. Continues: " you are one of the lights.

quotes.text: Always be a poet, even in prose.
quotes.author: Charles Baudelaire

quotes.text: I am the wound and the knife! I am the slap and the cheek!
quotes.author: Charles Baudelaire

quotes.text: Strangeness is a necessary ingredient in beauty.
quotes.author: Charles Baudelaire

quotes.text: The devil's finest trick is to persuade you that he does not exist.
quotes.author: Charles Baudelaire

quotes.text: What do I care that you are good? Be beautiful! and be sad!
quotes.author: Charles Baudelaire

quotes.text: One should always be drunk. That's all that matters.
quotes.author: Charles Baudelaire
quotes.attribution: Les Fleurs du Mal, 1857. Continues: "But with what? With wine, with poetry, or with virtue, as you chose."

quotes.text: Life is a hospital in which every patient is possessed with the desire to change beds.
quotes.author: Charles Baudelaire

quotes.text: I forged the chain I wear in life.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: A Christmas Carol, 1843. Continues: "; you wear such a chain yourself, and are making it link by link."

quotes.text: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: This is a London particular... A fog, miss.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: Dead, your Majesty. Dead, my lords and gentlemen.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Bleak House, 1853. Continues: "Dead, your honors, dead, your worships."

quotes.text: The universe makes rather an indifferent parent.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: I expect a judgment. Shortly.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Bleak House, 1853. Continues: "On the day the world shall end."

quotes.text: A loving heart is the truest wisdom.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: Suffering has been stronger than all other teaching.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: David Copperfield, 1850. Continues: ", and has taught me to understand what your heart used to be."

quotes.text: Heaven knows we need never be ashamed of tears.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Great Expectations, 1861. Continues: ", for they are rain upon the blinding dust of earth, overlying our hard hearts."

quotes.text: Facts alone are wanted in life.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: Plant nothing else, and root out everything else.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: There is a wisdom of the head, and a wisdom of the heart.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: Do the wise thing and the kind thing too.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Hard Times, 1854. Continues: ", and make the best of us and not the worst."

quotes.text: The only difference between us and the professors of virtue.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Hard Times, 1854. Continues: "is, that we avow what we do, and they don't."

quotes.text: Now, what I want is Facts.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Hard Times, 1854. Continues: "Teach these boys and girls nothing but Facts."

quotes.text: People mutht be amuthed.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Hard Times, 1854. Continues: "They can't be alwayth a working, nor yet they can't be alwayth a learning."

quotes.text: In our course through life we shall meet the people who are coming to meet us.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: While the flowers, pale and unreal in the moonlight, floated away upon the river.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: You will profit by the failure, and will avoid it another time.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: Every failure teaches a man something.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Little Dorrit, 1857. Continues: ", if he will learn."

quotes.text: Be guided only by the healer of the sick.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Little Dorrit, 1857. Continues: ", the raiser of the dead, the friend of all who were afflicted and forlorn."

quotes.text: It was but a momentary faltering.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Little Dorrit, 1857. Continues: "; and Little Dorrit,  seeing her shrunken figure in its ill-fitting dress,  immediately withdrew to her own room."

quotes.text: I am self-contained and self-reliant.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Little Dorrit, 1857. Continues: "; your opinion is nothing to me."

quotes.text: A prison taint was on everything there.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Little Dorrit, 1857. Continues: "The prisoners had crept along the rafters."

quotes.text: Charity begins at home, and justice begins next door.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: The pain of parting is nothing to the joy of meeting again.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens

quotes.text: Please, sir, I want some more.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Oliver Twist, 1838. Continues: " The board were sitting in solemn conclave, when Mr. Bumble rushed into the room in great excitement."

quotes.text: No one is useless in this world.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Our Mutual Friend, 1865. Continues: " who lightens the burdens of another."

quotes.text: Have a heart that never hardens.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: Our Mutual Friend, 1865. Continues: ", and a temper that never tires, and a touch that never hurts."

quotes.text: There are dark shadows on the earth.
quotes.author: Charles Dickens
quotes.attribution: The Pickwick Papers, 1837. Continues: ", but its lights are stronger in the contrast."

quotes.text: I am no bird; and no net ensnares me.
quotes.author: Charlotte Brontë

quotes.text: I would always rather be happy than dignified.
quotes.author: Charlotte Brontë

quotes.text: Life appears to me too short to be spent in nursing animosity or registering wrongs.
quotes.author: Charlotte Brontë

quotes.text: Reader, I married him.
quotes.author: Charlotte Brontë

quotes.text: Come buy, come buy.
quotes.author: Christina Rossetti

quotes.text: Goblin men with their fruits and their cries.
quotes.author: Christina Rossetti

quotes.text: In the bleak midwinter, frosty wind made moan.
quotes.author: Christina Rossetti

quotes.text: What can I give Him, poor as I am?
quotes.author: Christina Rossetti

quotes.text: All that we see or seem is but a dream within a dream.
quotes.author: Edgar Allan Poe

quotes.text: I was never really insane except upon occasions when my heart was touched.
quotes.author: Edgar Allan Poe

quotes.text: I became insane, with long intervals of horrible sanity.
quotes.author: Edgar Allan Poe

quotes.text: I have great faith in fools—self-confidence my friends call it.
quotes.author: Edgar Allan Poe

quotes.text: To vilify a great man is the readiest way in which a little man can himself attain greatness.
quotes.author: Edgar Allan Poe

quotes.text: Never to suffer would never to have been blessed.
quotes.author: Edgar Allan Poe

quotes.text: Words have no power to impress the mind without the exquisite horror of their reality.
quotes.author: Edgar Allan Poe
quotes.attribution: The Fall of the House of Usher, 1839.

quotes.text: The boundaries which divide Life from Death are at best shadowy and vague.
quotes.author: Edgar Allan Poe

quotes.text: Deep into that darkness peering, long I stood there, wondering, fearing.
quotes.author: Edgar Allan Poe

quotes.text: Believe nothing you hear, and only one half that you see.
quotes.author: Edgar Allan Poe

quotes.text: Books succeed, and lives fail.
quotes.author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning

quotes.text: Earth's crammed with heaven, and every common bush afire with God.
quotes.author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning

quotes.text: Light tomorrow with today!
quotes.author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning

quotes.text: The devil's most devilish when respectable.
quotes.author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning

quotes.text: Whoso loves believes the impossible.
quotes.author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning

quotes.text: God's gifts put man's best dreams to shame.
quotes.author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning

quotes.text: How do I love thee? Let me count the ways.
quotes.author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning

quotes.text: Come! Poor little heart! Be cheery and brave.
quotes.author: Elizabeth Gaskell

quotes.text: How different men were to women!
quotes.author: Elizabeth Gaskell

quotes.text: I have never loved any woman before: my life has been too busy.
quotes.author: Elizabeth Gaskell

quotes.text: I know you despise me; allow me to say, it is because you don't understand me.
quotes.author: Elizabeth Gaskell

quotes.text: Waiting is far more difficult than doing.
quotes.author: Elizabeth Gaskell

quotes.text: One forges one's style on the terrible anvil of daily deadlines.
quotes.author: Émile Zola

quotes.text: The artist is nothing without the gift, but the gift is nothing without work.
quotes.author: Émile Zola

quotes.text: Truth is on the march, and nothing will stop it.
quotes.author: Émile Zola

quotes.text: The past was but the cemetery of our illusions.
quotes.author: Émile Zola

quotes.text: He's more myself than I am.
quotes.author: Emily Brontë

quotes.text: If all else perished, and he remained, I should still continue to be.
quotes.author: Emily Brontë

quotes.text: Nelly, I am Heathcliff!
quotes.author: Emily Brontë

quotes.text: Whatever our souls are made of, his and mine are the same.
quotes.author: Emily Brontë

quotes.text: I have been bent and broken, but - I hope - into a better shape.
quotes.author: Emily Dickinson

quotes.text: If I read a book and it makes my whole body so cold no fire can warm me, I know that is poetry.
quotes.author: Emily Dickinson

quotes.text: Forever is composed of nows.
quotes.author: Emily Dickinson

quotes.text: Saying nothing sometimes says the most.
quotes.author: Emily Dickinson

quotes.text: That it will never come again is what makes life so sweet.
quotes.author: Emily Dickinson

quotes.text: I dwell in possibility.
quotes.author: Emily Dickinson

quotes.text: Parting is all we know of Heaven, and all we need of Hell.
quotes.author: Emily Dickinson

quotes.text: This is my letter to the world that never wrote to me.
quotes.author: Emily Dickinson

quotes.text: We are all bound up together in one great bundle of humanity,
quotes.author: Frances E.W. Harper
quotes.attribution: We Are All Bound Up Together, 1866. Continues "and society cannot trample on the weakest and feeblest of its members without receiving the curse in its own soul."

quotes.text: Apparent failure may hold in its rough shell the germs of a success that will blossom in time
quotes.author: Frances E.W. Harper,
quotes.attribution: Attributed ~1880s. Continues " and bear fruit throughout eternity."

quotes.text: Once you learn to read, you will be forever free.
quotes.author: Frederick Douglass

quotes.text: The soul that is within me no man can degrade.
quotes.author: Frederick Douglass

quotes.text: It is easier to build strong children than to repair broken men.
quotes.author: Frederick Douglass

quotes.text: If there is no struggle, there is no progress.
quotes.author: Frederick Douglass

quotes.text: Power concedes nothing without a demand. It never did and it never will.
quotes.author: Frederick Douglass

quotes.text: Taking a new step is what people fear most.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

quotes.text: To go wrong in one's own way is better.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: Crime and Punishment, 1866. Continues: " than to go right in someone else's."

quotes.text: If you want to overcome the whole world, overcome yourself.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

quotes.text: Man is a mystery. It needs to be unraveled.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: Letter, 1839. Continues: " and if I spend my whole life unraveling it, I will not say I wasted my time."

quotes.text: Man only likes to count his troubles.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: Notes from Underground, 1864. Continues: " but he does not count his joys."

quotes.text: Pain and suffering are always inevitable for a large intelligence.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: Poor Folk, 1846. Continues: " and a deep heart."

quotes.text: I am a poor, hungry, lonely man.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: Poor Folk, 1846. Continues: " and I am afraid of the future."

quotes.text: All my life I have been a dreamer.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: Poor Folk, 1846. Continues: " and I have lived in dreams."

quotes.text: I am a dreamer; I have so little real life.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: Poor Folk, 1846. Continues: " that I feel moments of real life as something unnatural."

quotes.text: I am a ridiculous man.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: Poor Folk, 1846. Continues: " They call me a madman now."

quotes.text: Much unhappiness comes from things left unsaid.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

quotes.text: To love someone means to see them as God intended.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

quotes.text: The mystery of human existence lies in just staying alive.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: The Brothers Karamazov, 1880. Continues: " but in finding something to live for."

quotes.text: Above all, don't lie to yourself.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: The Brothers Karamazov, 1880. Continues: " The man who lies to himself and listens to his own lie comes to a point that he cannot distinguish the truth within him."

quotes.text: I had a dream, and I wanted to live.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

quotes.text: I am a sick man... I am a spiteful man.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

quotes.text: I wanted to live for the sake of living.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
quotes.attribution: The Gambler, 1866. Continues: " I wanted to feel life in all its intensity."

quotes.text: The degree of civilization can be judged by entering its prisons.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

quotes.text: Beauty will save the world.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

quotes.text: The cleverest of all is the man who calls himself a fool once a month.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

quotes.text: The soul is healed by being with children.
quotes.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

quotes.text: A woman dictates before marriage in order that she may have an appetite for submission afterwards.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: Anger and jealousy can no more bear to lose sight of their objects than love.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: Blessed is the man who, having nothing to say, abstains from giving us wordy evidence of the fact.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: If youth is the season of hope, it is often so only in the sense that our elders are hopeful about us.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: It is a narrow mind which cannot look at a subject from various points of view.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: It is always fatal to have music or poetry interrupted.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: Our deeds determine us, as much as we determine our deeds.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: People are almost always better than their neighbours think they are.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: The strongest principle of growth lies in human choice.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: We are all of us born in moral stupidity, taking the world as an udder to feed our supreme selves.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: We mortals, men and women, devour many a disappointment between breakfast and dinner-time.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: What loneliness is more lonely than distrust?
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: The growing good of the world is partly dependent on unhistoric acts.
quotes.author: George Eliot
quotes.attribution: Middlemarch, 1871. Continues: " and that things are not so ill with you and me as they might have been."

quotes.text: Animals are such agreeable friends—they ask no questions; they pass no criticisms.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: Childhood has no forebodings; but then, it is soothed by no memories of outlived sorrow.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: I should like to know what is the proper function of women, if it is not to make reasons for husbands to stay at home.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: Life seems to go on without effort, when I am filled with music.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: The happiest women, like the happiest nations, have no history.
quotes.author: George Eliot

quotes.text: Guard well within yourself that treasure, kindness.
quotes.author: George Sand

quotes.text: The artist vocation is to send light into the human heart.
quotes.author: George Sand

quotes.text: Life resembles a novel more often than novels resemble life.
quotes.author: George Sand

quotes.text: There is only one happiness in life, to love and be loved.
quotes.author: George Sand

quotes.text: We cannot tear out a single page of our life, but we can throw the whole book in the fire.
quotes.author: George Sand

quotes.text: There is no truth. There is only perception.
quotes.author: Gustave Flaubert

quotes.text: Be regular and orderly in your life, so that you may be violent and original in your work.
quotes.author: Gustave Flaubert

quotes.text: Human speech is like a cracked kettle on which we tap crude rhythms for bears to dance to.
quotes.author: Gustave Flaubert
quotes.attribution: Madame Bovary, 1857. Continues: " while we long to make music that will melt the stars."

quotes.text: We breathe, sleep, drink, eat, work, and then die!
quotes.author: Guy de Maupassant

quotes.text: All depends on assurance, here.
quotes.author: Guy de Maupassant
quotes.attribution: Bel-Ami, 1885. Continues: "A shrewd, observing man can sometimes become a minister."

quotes.text: How strange and changeful is life!
quotes.author: Guy de Maupassant
quotes.attribution: Bel-Ami, 1885. Continues: "How small a thing is needed to make or ruin us!"

quotes.text: One can love a friend as much as a wife.
quotes.author: Guy de Maupassant
quotes.attribution: Bel-Ami, 1885. Continues: "Passion has its own laws."

quotes.text: You do not understand me now, but later on you will remember.
quotes.author: Guy de Maupassant

quotes.text: Men tire themselves in pursuits they believe are free.
quotes.author: Guy de Maupassant
quotes.attribution: Pierre et Jean, 1888. Continues: " but are in truth no more so than sheep in a meadow."

quotes.text: She danced madly, ecstatically, drunk with pleasure.
quotes.author: Guy de Maupassant

quotes.text: She suffered endlessly, feeling that she was meant for all the delicacies.
quotes.author: Guy de Maupassant

quotes.text: For women belong to no caste, no race.
quotes.author: Guy de Maupassant
quotes.attribution: The Necklace, 1884. Continues: " their grace, their beauty and their charm serving them in place of birth and family."

quotes.text: What would have happened if she had never lost those jewels?
quotes.author: Guy de Maupassant
quotes.attribution: The Necklace, 1884. Continues: "Who knows? How strange life is, how fickle!"

quotes.text: Adapt or perish, now as ever, is nature's inexorable imperative.
quotes.author: H.G. Wells
quotes.attribution: A Short History of the World, 1922.

quotes.text: If you fell down yesterday, stand up today.
quotes.author: H.G. Wells

quotes.text: The past is but the beginning of a beginning.
quotes.author: H.G. Wells

quotes.text: Human history becomes more and more a race between education and catastrophe.
quotes.author: H.G. Wells

quotes.text: We all have our time machines,  don't we
quotes.author: H.G. Wells
quotes.attribution: The Time Machine, 1895. Continues: " Some take us back, they're called memories. Some take us forward, they're called dreams."

quotes.text: He had been able to repress every disrespectful word; but the flashing eye, the gloomy and troubled brow, were part of a natural language.
quotes.author: Harriet Beecher Stowe
quotes.attribution: Dred: A Tale of the Great Dismal Swamp, 1856.

quotes.text: The bitterest tears shed over graves are for words left unsaid and deeds left undone.
quotes.author: Harriet Beecher Stowe
quotes.attribution: Dred: A Tale of the Great Dismal Swamp, 1856.

quotes.text: The truth is the kindest thing we can give folks in the end.
quotes.author: Harriet Beecher Stowe
quotes.attribution: Dred: A Tale of the Great Dismal Swamp, 1856.

quotes.text: When you get into a tight place and everything goes against you... never give up then.
quotes.author: Harriet Beecher Stowe
quotes.attribution: Dred: A Tale of the Great Dismal Swamp, 1856.

quotes.text: Any mind that is capable of real sorrow is capable of good.
quotes.author: Harriet Beecher Stowe

quotes.text: I am too high-born to be propertied, to be a secondary at control.
quotes.author: Harriet Beecher Stowe

quotes.text: Strange, what brings these past things so vividly back to us, sometimes!
quotes.author: Harriet Beecher Stowe

quotes.text: The longest way must have its close—the gloomiest night will wear on to a morning.
quotes.author: Harriet Beecher Stowe

quotes.text: Treat 'em like dogs, and you'll have dogs' work and dogs' wages.
quotes.author: Harriet Beecher Stowe

quotes.text: There can be no freedom or beauty about a home life that depends on borrowing and debt.
quotes.author: Henrik Ibsen

quotes.text: You have never loved me. You have only thought it pleasant to be in love with me.
quotes.author: Henrik Ibsen

quotes.text: I believe that before all else I am a human being.
quotes.author: Henrik Ibsen
quotes.attribution: A Doll's House, 1879. Continues: " just as much as you are—or at least I shall try to become one."

quotes.text: A marriage based on full confidence, based on complete and unqualified frankness on both sides.
quotes.author: Henrik Ibsen
quotes.attribution: A Doll's House, 1879. Continues: " they are not keeping anything back."

quotes.text: The strongest man in the world is he who stands most alone.
quotes.author: Henrik Ibsen

quotes.text: To live is to war with trolls in heart and soul.
quotes.author: Henrik Ibsen
quotes.attribution: Ghosts, 1881. Continues: " To write is to sit in judgment on oneself."

quotes.text: I am afraid of the half-lived life.
quotes.author: Henrik Ibsen

quotes.text: I have never had a home—only a cage.
quotes.author: Henrik Ibsen

quotes.text: I must try to make something of my life.
quotes.author: Henrik Ibsen
quotes.attribution: Hedda Gabler, 1890. Continues: " I must, I must!"

quotes.text: Money may be the husk of many things but not the kernel.
quotes.author: Henrik Ibsen
quotes.attribution: Hedda Gabler, 1890. Continues: " It brings you food, but not appetite."

quotes.text: Any fool can make a rule, and any fool will mind it.
quotes.author: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.text: I was not designed to be forced. I will breathe after my own fashion.
quotes.author: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.text: It is never too late to give up our prejudices.
quotes.author: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.text: The only obligation which I have a right to assume is to do at any time what I think right.
quotes.author: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.text: Under a government which imprisons any unjustly, the true place for a just man is also a prison.
quotes.author: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.text: I hear the wind among the trees playing celestial symphonies.
quotes.author: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.text: I went to the woods because I wished to live deliberately.
quotes.author: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.text: If a man does not keep pace with his companions, perhaps it is because he hears a different drummer.
quotes.author: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.text: The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation.
quotes.author: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.text: There is no remedy for love but to love more.
quotes.author: Henry David Thoreau

quotes.text: The art of being wise is knowing what to overlook.
quotes.author: Henry James

quotes.text: Summer afternoon—summer afternoon; to me those have always been the two most beautiful words.
quotes.author: Henry James

quotes.text: It's time to start living the life you've imagined.
quotes.author: Henry James

quotes.text: Live all you can; it's a mistake not to.
quotes.author: Henry James

quotes.text: The right time is any time that one is still so lucky as to have.
quotes.author: Henry James

quotes.text: Experience is never limited.
quotes.author: Henry James
quotes.attribution: The Ambassadors, 1903. Continues: " and it is never complete; it is an immense sensibility, a kind of huge spider-web of the finest silken threads suspended in the chamber of consciousness."

quotes.text: Ideas are the great warriors of the world.
quotes.author: Henry James

quotes.text: Be one of those on whom nothing is lost.
quotes.author: Henry James

quotes.text: The only obligation to which we may hold a novel.
quotes.author: Henry James
quotes.attribution: The Art of Fiction, 1884. Continues: " without a doubt, is that it be interesting."

quotes.text: We work in the dark - we do what we can.
quotes.author: Henry James
quotes.attribution: The Middle Years, 1893. Continues: " we give what we have. Our doubt is our passion, and our passion is our task."

quotes.text: I don't want everyone to like me; I should think less of myself if some people did.
quotes.author: Henry James

quotes.text: Do not mind anything that anyone tells you about anyone else.
quotes.author: Henry James
quotes.attribution: The Portrait of a Lady, 1881. Continues: " Judge everyone and everything for yourself."

quotes.text: Be not afraid of life.
quotes.author: Henry James
quotes.attribution: The Will to Believe, 1897. Continues: " Believe that life is worth living, and your belief will help create the fact."

quotes.text: Her memory's your love. You want no other.
quotes.author: Henry James

quotes.text: A whale-ship was my Yale College and my Harvard.
quotes.author: Herman Melville

quotes.text: All my means are sane, my motive and my object mad.
quotes.author: Herman Melville

quotes.text: Better to sleep with a sober cannibal than a drunk Christian.
quotes.author: Herman Melville

quotes.text: Call me Ishmael.
quotes.author: Herman Melville

quotes.text: I know not all that may be coming, but be it what it will, I'll go to it laughing.
quotes.author: Herman Melville

quotes.text: I love to sail forbidden seas, and land on barbarous coasts.
quotes.author: Herman Melville

quotes.text: I try all things, I achieve what I can.
quotes.author: Herman Melville

quotes.text: Ignorance is the parent of fear.
quotes.author: Herman Melville

quotes.text: Of all tools used in the shadow of the moon, men are most apt to get out of order.
quotes.author: Herman Melville

quotes.text: Talk not to me of blasphemy, man; I'd strike the sun if it insulted me.
quotes.author: Herman Melville

quotes.text: There is a wisdom that is woe.
quotes.author: Herman Melville
quotes.attribution: Moby-Dick, 1851. Continues: " but there is a woe that is madness."

quotes.text: Behind every great fortune lies a great crime.
quotes.author: Honoré de Balzac

quotes.text: Laws are spider webs through which the big flies pass and the little ones get caught.
quotes.author: Honoré de Balzac

quotes.text: If we wait for the moment when everything, absolutely everything is ready, we shall never begin.
quotes.author: Ivan Turgenev

quotes.text: Men will live like sheep when they have no wolves to fear.
quotes.author: James Fenimore Cooper

quotes.text: The woods are but the ears of the earth.
quotes.author: James Fenimore Cooper

quotes.text: History, like love, is so apt to surround her heroes with an atmosphere of imaginary brightness.
quotes.author: James Fenimore Cooper

quotes.text: I am Chingachgook, the Great Serpent of the Delawares.
quotes.author: James Fenimore Cooper

quotes.text: The air of the forest is the air of life.
quotes.author: James Fenimore Cooper

quotes.text: There is nothing like staying at home for real comfort.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: What is right to be done cannot be done too soon.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: Silly things do cease to be silly.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Emma, 1815. Continues: " if they are done by sensible people in an impudent way."

quotes.text: There is no charm equal to tenderness of heart.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Emma, 1815. Continues: "; there is nothing to be compared to it."

quotes.text: Selfishness must always be forgiven.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Mansfield Park, 1814. Continues: " you know, because there is no hope of a cure."

quotes.text: Life seems but a quick succession of busy nothings.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Mansfield Park, 1814. Continues: "; it was a quick succession of busy nothings till the carriage came to the door."

quotes.text: There is nothing I would not do for those who are really my friends.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: Friendship is certainly the finest balm.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Northanger Abbey, 1818. Continues: " for the pangs of disappointed love."

quotes.text: How quick come the reasons for approving what we like.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: Let us never underestimate the power of a well-written letter.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: One man's ways may be as good as another's, but we all like our own best.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: Time will explain.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: When pain is over, the remembrance of it often becomes a pleasure.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: There could have been no two hearts so open, no tastes so similar.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Persuasion, 1817. Continues: ", no feelings so in unison."

quotes.text: My idea of good company is the company of clever, well-informed people.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Persuasion, 1817. Continues: ", who have a great deal of conversation; that is what I call good company."

quotes.text: She hoped to be wise and reasonable in time.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Persuasion, 1817. Continues: "; but alas! Alas! She must confess to herself that she was not wise yet."

quotes.text: You pierce my soul. I am half agony, half hope.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Persuasion, 1817. Continues: "...I have loved none but you."

quotes.text: A man does not recover from such devotion of the heart to such a woman!
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Persuasion, 1817. Continues: "He ought not; he does not."

quotes.text: I hate to hear you talk about all women as if they were fine ladies.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: I could easily forgive his pride.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Pride and Prejudice, 1813. Continues: ", if he had not mortified mine."

quotes.text: Vanity and pride are different things.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Pride and Prejudice, 1813. Continues: ", though the words are often used synonymously."

quotes.text: Angry people are not always wise.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Pride and Prejudice, 1813. Continues: "; and in seeing him at last look somewhat nettled, she had all the success she expected."

quotes.text: A lady's imagination is very rapid.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Pride and Prejudice, 1813. Continues: "; it jumps from admiration to love, from love to matrimony in a moment."

quotes.text: My good opinion once lost is lost forever.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Pride and Prejudice, 1813. Continues: ". That is a failing indeed!"

quotes.text: I declare after all there is no enjoyment like reading!
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Pride and Prejudice, 1813. Continues: "How much sooner one tires of anything than of a book!"

quotes.text: Do not let the behavior of others destroy your inner peace.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: Elinor agreed to it all, for she did not think he deserved the compliment of rational opposition.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: I will be calm. I will be mistress of myself.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: If a book is well written, I always find it too short.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: If I could but know his heart, everything would become easy.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: It is not everyone who has your passion for dead leaves.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: She was stronger alone.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: To wish was to hope, and to hope was to expect.
quotes.author: Jane Austen

quotes.text: I come here with no expectations, only to profess.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Sense and Sensibility, 1811. Continues: ", now that I am at liberty to do so, that my heart is and always will be...yours."

quotes.text: I wish, as well as everybody else, to be perfectly happy.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Sense and Sensibility, 1811. Continues: "; but, like everybody else, it must be in my own way."

quotes.text: It is not time or opportunity that is to determine intimacy.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Sense and Sensibility, 1811. Continues: ";—it is disposition alone."

quotes.text: The more I know of the world, the more I am convinced that I shall never see a man whom I can really love.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Sense and Sensibility, 1811. Continues: "I require so much!"

quotes.text: Know your own happiness.
quotes.author: Jane Austen
quotes.attribution: Sense and Sensibility, 1811. Continues: "You want nothing but patience—or give it a more fascinating name, call it hope."

quotes.text: A thing of beauty is a joy forever.
quotes.author: John Keats

quotes.text: Beauty is truth, truth beauty.
quotes.author: John Keats

quotes.text: The past is an illusion.
quotes.author: José Maria Eça de Queirós

quotes.text: The world is a comedy to those that think, a tragedy to those who feel.
quotes.author: José Maria Eça de Queirós

quotes.text: It is certain that inanimate objects have a direct action on the brain.
quotes.author: Jules Verne
quotes.attribution: Around the World in Eighty Days, 1873.

quotes.text: The chance which now seems lost may present itself at the last moment.
quotes.author: Jules Verne
quotes.attribution: Around the World in Eighty Days, 1873.

quotes.text: Reality provides us with facts so romantic that imagination itself could add nothing.
quotes.author: Jules Verne

quotes.text: However, everything has an end, even the hunger of people who have not eaten.
quotes.author: Jules Verne

quotes.text: What is there unreasonable in admitting the existence of worlds besides our own?
quotes.author: Jules Verne
quotes.attribution: From the Earth to the Moon, 1865.

quotes.text: Solitude, isolation, are painful things and beyond human endurance.
quotes.author: Jules Verne

quotes.text: Liberty is worth paying for.
quotes.author: Jules Verne
quotes.attribution: Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea, 1870.

quotes.text: The sea is the vast reservoir of Nature.
quotes.author: Jules Verne
quotes.attribution: Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea, 1870.

quotes.text: A feeling of exultation overtook her, as if some power of significant import had been given her to control the working of her body and soul.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: He did not know; perhaps he would never know.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: One of these days, she said, I’m going to pull myself together for a while and think—try to determine what character of a woman I am.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: She felt like some new-born creature, opening its eyes in a familiar world that it had never known.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: She wanted to swim far out, where no woman had swum before.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: She was becoming herself and daily casting aside that fictitious self.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: The bird that would soar above the level plain of tradition and prejudice must have strong wings.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: The past was nothing to her; offered no lesson which she was willing to heed.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: The sea is a lonely place, and the night is very long.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: The touch of the sea is sensuous, enfolding the body in its soft, close embrace.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: The voice of the sea speaks to the soul.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: There were days when she was unhappy, she did not know why.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin

quotes.text: I would give up the unessential; I would give my money, I would give my life for my children.
quotes.author: Kate Chopin
quotes.attribution: The Awakening, 1899. Continues: " but I wouldn’t give myself."

quotes.text: If you look for perfection, you'll never be content.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: Respect was invented to cover the empty place where love should be.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: Spring is the time of plans and projects.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: All happy families are alike.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy
quotes.attribution: Anna Karenina, 1877. Continues: " each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way."

quotes.text: True life is lived when tiny changes occur.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: The sole meaning of life is to serve humanity.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: I am always with myself, and it is I who am my tormentor.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: If a man does not love, he is not alive.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: Love is life. All, everything that I understand, I understand only because I love.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: The body will die, but I feel that I am eternal.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: I sit on a man's back, choking him and making him carry me.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy
quotes.attribution: Resurrection, 1899. Continues: " and yet assure myself and others that I am very sorry for him."

quotes.text: People are like rivers: the water is the same in all.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy
quotes.attribution: Resurrection, 1899. Continues: " but every river is narrow here, rapid there, wide again."

quotes.text: The most difficult and complicated thing in life is to love.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: Death is finished, it is no more!
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: He sought his old habitual fear of death and could not find it.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: In place of death there was light.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: Ivan Ilyich's life had been most simple and most ordinary and therefore most terrible.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: What if my whole life has been wrong?
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: Can it be that I have not lived as one ought?
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy
quotes.attribution: The Death of Ivan Ilyich, 1886. Continues: " he suddenly asked himself."

quotes.text: Maybe I did not live as I ought to have done.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy
quotes.attribution: The Death of Ivan Ilyich, 1886. Continues: " he thought."

quotes.text: It occurred to him that what had appeared perfectly impossible before...
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy
quotes.attribution: The Death of Ivan Ilyich, 1886. Continues: "—that he had not spent his life as he should have done—might after all be true."

quotes.text: Everyone thinks of changing the world.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy
quotes.attribution: The Kingdom of God Is Within You, 1894. Continues: " but no one thinks of changing himself."

quotes.text: Everything comes in time to him who knows how to wait.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: The two most powerful warriors are patience and time.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy

quotes.text: We can know only that we know nothing.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy
quotes.attribution: War and Peace, 1869. Continues: " And that is the highest degree of human wisdom."

quotes.text: In the name of God, stop a moment.
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy
quotes.attribution: War and Peace, 1869. Continues: " cease your work, look around you."

quotes.text: Seize the moments of happiness, love and be loved!
quotes.author: Leo Tolstoy
quotes.attribution: War and Peace, 1869. Continues: " That is the only reality in the world, all else is folly."

quotes.text: Begin at the beginning, and go on till you come to the end: then stop.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: Everything's got a moral, if only you can find it.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: I can't go back to yesterday because I was a different person then.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: I give myself very good advice, but I very seldom follow it.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: If everybody minded their own business, the world would go around a great deal faster.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: Tut, tut, child! Everything's got a moral, if only you can find it.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: Who in the world am I? Ah, that's the great puzzle.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: It takes all the running you can do, to keep in the same place.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: Speak in French when you can't think of the English for a thing.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: The rule is, jam tomorrow and jam yesterday—but never jam today.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: Why, sometimes I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll

quotes.text: When I use a word, it means just what I choose it to mean.
quotes.author: Lewis Carroll
quotes.attribution: Through the Looking-Glass, 1871. Continues: "—neither more nor less."

quotes.text: I like good strong words that mean something.
quotes.author: Louisa  May Alcott

quotes.text: Be worthy love, and love will come.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott

quotes.text: Stay is a charming word in a friend's vocabulary.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott

quotes.text: Women have been called queens for a long time.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott
quotes.attribution: An Old-Fashioned Girl, 1869. Continues: " but the kingdom given them isn't worth ruling."

quotes.text: Far away there in the sunshine are my highest aspirations.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott
quotes.attribution: Attributed, ~1860s. Continues: " I may not reach them, but I can look up and see their beauty."

quotes.text: Life is my college.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott
quotes.attribution: Good Wives, 1869. Continues: " May I graduate well, and earn some honors!"

quotes.text: Some books are so familiar reading them is like being home again.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott

quotes.text: Let my name stand among those who are willing to bear ridicule.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott
quotes.attribution: Letter, 1862. Continues: " for the sake of doing good."

quotes.text: I like good strong words that mean something.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott

quotes.text: I'd rather take coffee than compliments.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott

quotes.text: Love alone is a beautiful thing.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott

quotes.text: She is too fond of books, and it has turned her brain.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott

quotes.text: I've got the key to my castle in the air.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott
quotes.attribution: Little Women, 1868. Continues: " but whether it will open the door remains to be seen."

quotes.text: Love will make small powers great.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott

quotes.text: Nothing is impossible to a determined woman.
quotes.author: Louisa May Alcott

quotes.text: I am the sum of my ancestors.
quotes.author: Machado de Assis

quotes.text: To forgive is divine, not human.
quotes.author: Machado de Assis

quotes.text: Each person is a universe.
quotes.author: Machado de Assis
quotes.attribution: The Posthumous Memoirs of Brás Cubas, 1881.

quotes.text: I am a book with a missing page.
quotes.author: Machado de Assis
quotes.attribution: The Posthumous Memoirs of Brás Cubas, 1881.

quotes.text: I have always been a man of few words and many thoughts.
quotes.author: Machado de Assis
quotes.attribution: The Posthumous Memoirs of Brás Cubas, 1881.

quotes.text: The best chess player is the one who thinks he is the worst.
quotes.author: Machado de Assis
quotes.attribution: The Posthumous Memoirs of Brás Cubas, 1881.

quotes.text: I have never let my schooling interfere with my education.
quotes.author: Mark Twain
quotes.attribution: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court, 1889.

quotes.text: The very ink with which all history is written is merely fluid prejudice.
quotes.author: Mark Twain
quotes.attribution: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court, 1889.

quotes.text: Words are only painted fire; a look is the fire itself.
quotes.author: Mark Twain
quotes.attribution: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court, 1889.

quotes.text: You can’t depend on your eyes when your imagination is out of focus.
quotes.author: Mark Twain
quotes.attribution: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court, 1889.

quotes.text: Human beings can be awful cruel to one another.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: I felt so lonesome I most wished I was dead.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: I reckon I got to light out for the Territory ahead of the rest.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: You don’t know about me without you have read a book by the name of The Adventures of Tom Sawyer.
quotes.author: Mark Twain
quotes.attribution: Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, 1884. Continues: " but that ain’t no matter."

quotes.text: All right, then, I’ll go to hell.
quotes.author: Mark Twain
quotes.attribution: Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, 1884. Continues: "—and tore it up."

quotes.text: Don't go around saying the world owes you a living. The world owes you nothing.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: Kindness is the language which the deaf can hear and the blind can see.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: The man who does not read has no advantage over the man who cannot read.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: Truth is stranger than fiction, but it is because fiction is obliged to stick to possibilities.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: Give every day the chance to become the most beautiful day of your life.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: Never put off till tomorrow what may be done day after tomorrow just as well.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: Always do right. This will gratify some people and astonish the rest.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: When in doubt, tell the truth.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: The secret of getting ahead is getting started.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: Good friends, good books, and a sleepy conscience: this is the ideal life.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: The lack of money is the root of all evil.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: When you fish for love, bait with your heart, not your brain.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: Courage is resistance to fear, mastery of fear—not absence of fear.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.text: Tom and me found the money that the robbers hid in the cave.
quotes.author: Mark Twain
quotes.attribution: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, 1876. Continues: " and it made us rich."

quotes.text: I ain’t doing my duty by that boy, and that’s the Lord’s truth.
quotes.author: Mark Twain
quotes.attribution: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, 1876. Continues: " goodness knows."

quotes.text: Work consists of whatever a body is obliged to do.
quotes.author: Mark Twain
quotes.attribution: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, 1876. Continues: " Play consists of whatever a body is not obliged to do."

quotes.text: Beware; for I am fearless, and therefore powerful.
quotes.author: Mary Shelley

quotes.text: I ought to be thy Adam, but I am rather the fallen angel.
quotes.author: Mary Shelley

quotes.text: If I cannot inspire love, I will cause fear.
quotes.author: Mary Shelley

quotes.text: Nothing is so painful to the human mind as a great and sudden change.
quotes.author: Mary Shelley

quotes.text: The world was to me a secret which I desired to divine.
quotes.author: Mary Shelley

quotes.text: Learn from me, if not by my precepts, at least by my example.
quotes.author: Mary Shelley
quotes.attribution: Frankenstein, 1818. Continues: " how dangerous is the acquirement of knowledge."

quotes.text: Come to the window, sweet is the night-air!
quotes.author: Matthew Arnold

quotes.text: The eternal note of sadness.
quotes.author: Matthew Arnold

quotes.text: No man can wear one face to himself and another to the multitude without getting bewildered.
quotes.author: Nathaniel Hawthorne

quotes.text: The longer and more carefully we look at a funny story, the sadder it becomes.
quotes.author: Nikolai Gogol

quotes.text: I can resist everything except temptation.
quotes.author: Oscar Wilde

quotes.text: We are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars.
quotes.author: Oscar Wilde

quotes.text: Education is an admirable thing, but nothing worth knowing can be taught.
quotes.author: Oscar Wilde

quotes.text: I am so clever that sometimes I don't understand a single word of what I am saying.
quotes.author: Oscar Wilde
quotes.attribution: The Happy Prince and Other Stories, 1888.

quotes.text: The truth is rarely pure and never simple.
quotes.author: Oscar Wilde

quotes.text: Experience is merely the name men gave to their mistakes.
quotes.author: Oscar Wilde

quotes.text: The only way to get rid of a temptation is to yield to it.
quotes.author: Oscar Wilde

quotes.text: To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist, that is all.
quotes.author: Oscar Wilde
quotes.attribution: The Soul of Man Under Socialism, 1891.

quotes.text: Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!
quotes.author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quotes.text: Do not go where the path may lead, go instead where there is no path and leave a trail.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: For every minute you are angry you lose sixty seconds of happiness.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Life is a journey, not a destination.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The only person you are destined to become is the person you decide to be.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: To be yourself in a world that is constantly trying to make you something else is the greatest accomplishment.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Ah, but a man's reach should exceed his grasp, or what's a heaven for?
quotes.author: Robert Browning

quotes.text: Grow old along with me! The best is yet to be.
quotes.author: Robert Browning

quotes.text: The world is so full of a number of things, I'm sure we should all be as happy as kings.
quotes.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

quotes.text: I am not afraid to die, but I am afraid to be forgotten.
quotes.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
quotes.attribution: Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde, 1886.

quotes.text: It is one thing to mortify curiosity, another to conquer it.
quotes.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
quotes.attribution: Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde, 1886.

quotes.text: I have seen wicked men and fools, a great many of both.
quotes.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

quotes.text: If you keep on drinking rum, the world will soon be quit of a very dirty scoundrel!
quotes.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

quotes.text: Many's the long night I've dreamed of cheese—toasted, mostly.
quotes.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

quotes.text: The world belongs to the discontented.
quotes.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

quotes.text: If you can keep your head when all about you are losing theirs.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: If you can meet with Triumph and Disaster and treat those two impostors just the same.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: Yours is the Earth and everything that’s in it.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling
quotes.attribution: If—, 1895. Continues: " And—which is more—you’ll be a Man, my son!"

quotes.text: A man’s mind is wont to tell him more than seven watchmen posted on a high tower.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: Everyone is more or less mad on one point.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: He who can keep alive a sense of humour in the face of disaster is more than half armed.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: I am Kim. I am Kim. And what is Kim?
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: Of all the liars in the world, sometimes the worst are our own fears.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: This is a great and terrible world. I never knew there were so many men alive in it.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: Words are, of course, the most powerful drug used by mankind.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: The world is very lovely, and it’s very horrible.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling
quotes.attribution: Kim, 1901. Continues: " and it doesn’t care about your life or mine or anything else."

quotes.text: A brave heart and a courteous tongue.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling
quotes.attribution: Kim, 1901. Continues: " They shall carry thee far through the jungle, manling."

quotes.text: For the strength of the Pack is the Wolf, and the strength of the Wolf is the Pack.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: If you can’t ride two horses at once, you shouldn’t be in the circus.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: We be of one blood, ye and I.
quotes.author: Rudyard Kipling

quotes.text: Truth is powerful and it prevails.
quotes.author: Sojourner Truth

quotes.text: I am not going to die,  I'm going home like a shooting star.
quotes.author: Sojourner Truth

quotes.text: Religion without humanity is very poor human stuff.
quotes.author: Sojourner Truth

quotes.text: A novel is a mirror carried along a high road.
quotes.author: Stendhal
quotes.attribution: The Red and the Black, 1830. Continues: " At one moment you see the sky, at another the mud."

quotes.text: The world passes him by and beckons to life and beauty.
quotes.author: Theodor Fontane

quotes.text: Nothing holds out these days, and next thing you know we'll be counting those who are famous by days.
quotes.author: Theodor Fontane

quotes.text: We should love what is old, to the extent that it deserves it.
quotes.author: Theodor Fontane
quotes.attribution: The Stechlin, 1898. Continues: " but we should really live for what is new."

quotes.text: Happiness, it seems to me, consists of two things.
quotes.author: Theodor Fontane
quotes.attribution: The Stechlin, 1898. Continues: " first, in being where you belong, and second -- in comfortably going through everyday life."

quotes.text: A man's silence is wonderful to listen to.
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy

quotes.text: People go on marrying because they can't resist natural forces.
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy

quotes.text: The letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life.
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy

quotes.text: The only way to live is to forget.
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy

quotes.text: Somebody might have come along that way who would have asked him his trouble.
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy
quotes.attribution: Jude the Obscure, 1895. Continues: " and he would have answered, 'I have none.'"

quotes.text: It is a city of light, where the streets are paved with gold.
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy
quotes.attribution: Jude the Obscure, 1895. Continues: " and the gates are of pearl."

quotes.text: A strong woman who recklessly throws away her strength, she is worse than a weak woman who has never had any strength to throw away.
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy

quotes.text: Beauty lay not in the thing, but in what the thing symbolized.
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy

quotes.text: Ladies know what to guard against, because they read novels that tell them.
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy

quotes.text: The beauty or ugliness of a character lay not only in its acts, but in its aims.
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy

quotes.text: Why is it that a woman’s silence can be so powerful?
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy

quotes.text: Did you say the stars were worlds, Tess?
quotes.author: Thomas Hardy
quotes.attribution: Tess of the d'Urbervilles, 1891. Continues: "Yes."All like ours?"I don't know, but I think so."

quotes.text: He who opens a school door, closes a prison.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo

quotes.text: Even the darkest night will end and the sun will rise.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo

quotes.text: Laughter is the sun that drives winter from the human face.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo

quotes.text: The greatest happiness of life is the conviction that we are loved.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo

quotes.text: To learn to read is to light a fire; every syllable that is spelled out is a spark.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo

quotes.text: To love another person is to see the face of God.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo

quotes.text: He left the cathedral, but the cathedral did not leave him.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo

quotes.text: A one-eyed man is much more incomplete than a blind man.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo
quotes.attribution: The Hunchback of Notre-Dame, 1831. Continues: " for he knows what he is missing."

quotes.text: To be wicked does not insure prosperity.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo
quotes.attribution: The Hunchback of Notre-Dame, 1831. Continues: " for the inn did not succeed well."

quotes.text: The greatest products of architecture are social creations.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo
quotes.attribution: The Hunchback of Notre-Dame, 1831. Continues: " more than the work of individual minds."

quotes.text: The most beautiful things in the world are the most useless.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo
quotes.attribution: The Hunchback of Notre-Dame, 1831. Continues: " peacocks and lilies, for example."

quotes.text: Love is like a tree: it grows by itself.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo
quotes.attribution: The Hunchback of Notre-Dame, 1831. Continues: " roots itself deeply in our being."

quotes.text: To struggle against the sea is to struggle against God.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo

quotes.text: The ocean is a wilderness reaching round the globe.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo
quotes.attribution: Toilers of the Sea, 1866. Continues: " a desert where man is never alone."

quotes.text: The sea is a world of darkness.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo
quotes.attribution: Toilers of the Sea, 1866. Continues: " but it is also a world of light."

quotes.text: Persons who go to the bottom of the sea are forever lost.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo
quotes.attribution: Toilers of the Sea, 1866. Continues: " but they are not forever forgotten."

quotes.text: A man is not idle because he is absorbed in thought.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo
quotes.attribution: Toilers of the Sea, 1866. Continues: " There is visible labor and invisible labor."

quotes.text: The sea is a space of infinite solitude.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo
quotes.attribution: Toilers of the Sea, 1866. Continues: " where man is never alone, for he feels life stirring on all sides."

quotes.text: Music expresses that which cannot be said and on which it is impossible to be silent.
quotes.author: Victor Hugo

quotes.text: I sing the body electric.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: Resist much, obey little.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: Keep your face always toward the sunshine.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman
quotes.attribution: Leaves of Grass, 1855. Continues: " and shadows will fall behind you."

quotes.text: Every moment of light and dark is a miracle.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: The powerful play goes on, and you may contribute a verse.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: Simplicity is the glory of expression.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: Whatever satisfies the soul is truth.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: Do I contradict myself? Very well then I contradict myself.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: I am large, I contain multitudes.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: I believe a leaf of grass is no less than the journey-work of the stars.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: I celebrate myself, and sing myself.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: I exist as I am, that is enough.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: These are the days that must happen to you.
quotes.author: Walt Whitman

quotes.text: Let my grave be forgotten.
quotes.author: Wilkie Collins

quotes.text: There is much that I might say about the merciless treatment of me.
quotes.author: Wilkie Collins

quotes.text: You are not to take it as the saying of an ignorant man.
quotes.author: Wilkie Collins

quotes.text: Your tears come easy, when you're young, and beginning the world.
quotes.author: Wilkie Collins

quotes.text: Whenever a woman tries to put you out of temper.
quotes.author: Wilkie Collins
quotes.attribution: The Moonstone, 1868. Continues: " turn the tables, and put HER out of temper instead."

quotes.text: I am a bundle of nerves dressed up to look like a man!
quotes.author: Wilkie Collins

quotes.text: I sadly want a reform in the construction of children.
quotes.author: Wilkie Collins

quotes.text: She looked so irresistibly beautiful as she said those brave words.
quotes.author: Wilkie Collins

quotes.text: Take care how you treat your wife, and how you threaten me.
quotes.author: Wilkie Collins

quotes.text: I don't suppose that anything you could do would make me like you any less.
quotes.author: William Dean Howells

quotes.text: The mortality of all inanimate things is terrible to me, but that of books most of all.
quotes.author: William Dean Howells

quotes.text: The world is full of people who are not worth talking about.
quotes.author: William Dean Howells

quotes.text: The secret of the man who is universally interesting is that he is universally interested.
quotes.author: William Dean Howells

quotes.text: There is more in the education of circumstances than many suppose.
quotes.author: William Dean Howells

quotes.text: All is vanity, nothing is fair.
quotes.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

quotes.text: Mother is the name for God in the lips and hearts of little children.
quotes.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

quotes.text: The world is a looking-glass, and gives back to every man the reflection of his own face.
quotes.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

quotes.text: Vanity working on a weak head produces every sort of mischief.
quotes.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

quotes.text: Fill your paper with the breathings of your heart.
quotes.author: William Wordsworth

quotes.text: The best portion of a good man's life: his little, nameless unremembered acts of kindness and love.
quotes.author: William Wordsworth
